2.definition: A volumetric processing mode that uses triplets of consecutive slices (z-1, z, z+1) as input to predict the center slice, leveraging inter-slice context for better denoising

G.definition: A smoothing filter using weights that follow a bell curve (Gaussian) distribution, giving more weight to nearby pixels
Human-created labels that represent the correct answer, used to train and evaluate machine learning models

S.definition: A training approach where the model learns from the data itself without requiring manually labeled ground truth
Temporary file storage that exists only during your login session  files are cleared when the session ends
The standard deviation of the Gaussian distribution - controls how quickly weights decrease with distance
A single 2D image within a 3D image stack, typically representing one focal plane or time point
Stereolithography format - a common file format for 3D printing that stores triangle mesh geometry
Noise with spatial patterns or correlations, such as scan lines or periodic artifacts, as opposed to random pixel-independent noise
A 3D representation composed of vertices (points) and faces (triangles) that approximate the surface of an object

D.definition: The process of removing unwanted noise from images while preserving important features and details

B.definition: An action performed on multiple selected files at once, such as batch download or batch delete
A network architecture that cannot see the center pixel when predicting it, preventing the trivial solution of copying noisy values
A painting tool that applies the current class label to pixels as you draw

A.definition: A labeled mask where each pixel is assigned to a class (background or object categories)
A two-stage extension of N2V that automatically detects and removes structured noise patterns through Fourier analysis

W.definition: The collection of all files in your current session, organized into categories for different processing stages
A compressed archive containing your entire workspace, used for backup and restore between sessions

I.definition: A series of 2D images stored together, representing a 3D volume or time series

M.definition: An algorithm that extracts a polygonal mesh from a 3D scalar field (like a labeled image stack) by finding surface boundaries
An image where pixel values represent class labels rather than visual intensity
The process of analyzing N2V residuals in Fourier space to detect periodic noise patterns for Stage 2 training
A 3D surface representation composed of vertices (points) and faces (triangles)

C.definition: A category of pixels in a segmentation task, such as 'cell', 'background', or 'nucleus'
Limiting the visible region of a 3D object to reveal internal structure

P.definition: Moving the viewing area across a zoomed image by clicking and dragging
A small rectangular region of pixels used for comparison in NLM denoising

N.definition: A self-supervised denoising method that trains by predicting masked pixels from their surroundings, requiring no clean reference images
A denoising algorithm that averages similar patches from across the entire image, not just nearby pixels

L.definition: The processing history of a file, tracking which source files were used to create it

F.definition: Triangular surfaces in a mesh, each defined by three vertices
The processing history of a file, showing which modules created it and from what source files

T.definition: A JavaScript 3D graphics library used for rendering and animating 3D content in web browsers
Tagged Image File Format - a flexible image format commonly used in microscopy for storing multi-page image stacks
Three consecutive slices from a stack used as input in 2.5D mode: the slice above (z-1), the center slice (z), and the slice below (z+1)

V.definition: Error measured on held-out data not used for training, indicating how well the model generalizes to new images
The corner points of triangles in a mesh, defined by X, Y, Z coordinates

O.definition: Wavefront OBJ - a simple text-based 3D geometry format widely supported by 3D software
The degree to which an object blocks light - 100% is fully solid, lower values are more transparent

K.definition: The filter window - a small matrix of weights applied to each pixel and its neighbors

Z.definition: Magnification level for viewing images - values above 100% show enlarged detail, below 100% shows a wider view
